chapter.title: Pronouns
chapter.para: Pronouns are pointers to a noun. These are some common singular pronouns:
These are some common plural pronouns:
In technical writing, pronouns are simplified because English doesn't assign gender to inorganic things.

note.para: If you are writing a use case and need to reference a fictional human, it's common to use generic terms, such as a job title instead of an arbitrary name, such as "John" or "Jane", and the pronoun "they" instead of "him" or "her".

section.title: How to use pronouns
section.para: For pronouns to work as designed, they require two things:

listitem.para: The reader must know what noun the pronoun references.
The tense of the pronoun and its noun and verb must match.

formalpara.title: Singular noun
formalpara.para: When referring back to a singular noun, use the pronoun it. For example:

section.para: The server is running RHEL 7, and it has 8 TB of storage.

formalpara.title: Plural pronouns
formalpara.para: When referring back to a plural noun, use the pronoun they. For example:

section.para: Desktop computers often get used for office tasks, but they can also be configured as servers for a small network.

formalpara.title: Possessive pronouns
formalpara.para: To indicate that a pronoun possesses something, use a the possessive form of the appropriate pronoun. For example:

section.para: Emacs is a text editor, but its real power is its LISP interpreter.
The same applies for plural forms:
Open source programmers are brave to subject their code to the scrutiny of anyone who wants to look at it.

formalpara.title: Pronouns in context
formalpara.para: Sometimes a pronoun is used in a separate sentence from the one that establishes the noun it references. This relies on the reader to understand from context which noun the pronoun most likely refers to.

section.para: Sometimes it is very obvious. In the phrase "I like drinking coffee while I sit and type at my computer. Sometimes, I even dunk a doughnut into it," the reader knows from contextual clues that the writer means "Sometimes, I even dunk a doughnut into my coffee" and not "Sometimes, I even dunk a doughnut into my computer."

Sometimes it is less obvious. In the phrase "The foo command is working to replace the bar command. It is installed by default, and it has a bug in it that erases all of your data permanently, so must not be used," the reader cannot know definitively which command erases all of their data and which command is safe. Sometimes, using a pronoun is not as effective as being explicit.

formalpara.title: Verify your pronouns
formalpara.para: To verify that a pronoun makes sense, reread a sentence or paragraph, replacing the pronoun you chose with the subject: For example:

section.para: Desktop computers often get used for office tasks, but desktop computers can also be configured as servers for a small network.

If it still says what you meant to say, then you have placed the pronoun in the correct place. If it does not make sense, or if it impossible to read back with its subject replaced because there is no indication of what the correct subject is, then the pronoun has not been used correctly.

listitem.para: The systems administrators imaged the computers so that its host names followed a logical naming scheme.
Return the laptop to the store and get refunded for them.
Okular is the best PDF viewer on the market. Admittedly, it's not the best format for digital releases compared to EPUB, but it's great for printing.
The systems administrators imaged each computer so that its host name followed a logical naming scheme.
